metadata.title: Catalytic reduction of nitrite in water over ceria- and ceria–zirconia-supported Pd catalysts
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

PC PCZ1 PCZ2 PCZ3 Ce3+ concentration (%) 27.1 34.9 31.4 24.9 A c /A t (%) 25.1 30.2 26.4 23.8 Catalytic reduction of nitrite in water over ceria- and ceria–zirconia-supported Pd catalysts Jiyeon Lee a Young Gul Hur a Min-Sung Kim a ⁎ Kwan-Young Lee a b ⁎⁎ a Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering, Korea University, 145, Anam-ro, Seongbuk-gu, Seoul 136-701, Republic of Korea Department of Chemical and Biological Engineering Korea University 145, Anam-ro Seongbuk-gu Seoul 136-701 Republic of Korea b Green School, Korea University, 145, Anam-ro, Seongbuk-gu, Seoul 136-701, Republic of Korea Green School Korea University 145, Anam-ro Seongbuk-gu Seoul 136-701 Republic of Korea ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 2 3290 3299; fax: +82 2 926 6102. ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +82 2 3290 3727; fax: +82 2 926 6102. Graphical abstract In this study, we tested Pd/Ce1− x Zr x O2 catalysts (x =0, 0.3, 0.5 and 0.7) for nitrite reduction in water. The Ce1− x Zr x O2 was synthesized by the co-precipitation method, and Pd was impregnated on the support using the deposition–precipitation method. The introduction of Zr into the ceria lattice of the catalyst with x =0.3 and 0.5 distorted the lattice structure, accordingly, both the catalysts easily reduced nitrite than the pure CeO2 supported Pd catalyst. In contrast, the Pd/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 (x =0.7) catalyst became difficult to reduce as the tetragonal ZrO2 phase was dominant in the catalyst structure. These phenomena led to the difference in the amount of oxygen vacancies on the surface of the catalyst. In the nitrite reduction test, the catalyst containing more oxygen vacancies showed higher activity. The relationships between the catalytic activities and the surface properties with composition of the support over Pd/Ce1− x Zr x O2 catalysts were investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses. Keywords Nitrite reduction Hydrogenation Ce1− x Zr x O2 Oxygen vacancy 1 Introduction In recent years, drinking water is increasingly contaminated with nitrite (NO2 −), resulting from the overuse of fertilizer in agriculture and the discharge of industrial wastewater [1]. Because nitrite overexposure in the human body can cause cancer, lung disease and blue-baby syndrome [1–3], the World Health Organization and European Community have determined 0.1 and 0.02mg/L as the permissible nitrite levels, respectively [2,4]. Because of increasing concerns on the nitrite pollution, various physicochemical (e.g., ion exchange and reverse osmosis) and biological treatments have been used for the nitrite reduction [5,6]; however, each process revealed disadvantage such as need of the secondary treatment process in the former and slow reaction rate in the latter [6]. To solve these problems, Vorlop and Tacke first reported a catalytic reduction method [7] which is performed under mild conditions (T =25°C and P =1atm) using a single noble metal supported catalyst and hydrogen gas as the reducing agent, and the reaction is as follows [8]: NO2 − +3H2 →N2 +2H2O+2OH− Hörold et al. tested diverse noble metal impregnated catalysts, which were Pd, Pt, Ru, Ir and Rh on Al2O3 support, and found that only the Pd supported catalyst was effective for the nitrite reduction [2,8]. Along with active metals, many studies aimed to investigate suitable supports such as Al2O3 [9,10], carbon fiber [11] and conducting polymers [12], because different surface state of the utilized supports could enhance the nitrite reduction. Recently, we studied the performances of Pd–Cu/TiO2 and Pd–Cu/TiO2–CeO2 catalysts for the nitrate (NO3 −) reduction in water [13,14], indicating that oxygen vacancies formed on the reducible TiO2 and TiO2–CeO2 supports play an important role in promoting the activity. Gavagnin et al. and Guo et al. also claimed that the catalysts including high oxygen vacancy were very active for the nitrate reduction [15,16]. Hence, the study on the effect of oxygen vacancies on the nitrite reduction activity is needed. The above mentioned studies show that the oxygen vacancies could be generated on reducible oxides (e.g., TiO2, CeO2, and SnO2) [14,15,17]. Furthermore, the formation of oxygen vacancies was also observed on mixed oxides (e.g., Ce1− x M x O2; M=Si4+, Ti4+ and Zr4+), resulting from the incorporation of other components into CeO2 crystalline lattice, thereby changing the textural properties [18–20]. Among different materials, the Ce1− x Zr x O2 mixed oxides have been widely used in various research areas. For Pt catalysts in the partial oxidation of methane, the addition of Zr to the CeO2 lattice increased the number of oxygen vacancies, enhancing the performance of Pt/Ce1− x Zr x O2 than that of Pt/CeO2 [21]. Similarly, the oxygen vacancies on the Ce1− x Zr x O2 supported Cu catalysts acted as active sites for capturing CO and CO2, and consequently, high yield of methanol from CO/CO2/H2 gas was obtained using Cu/Ce0.7Zr0.3O2 catalyst [22]. Based on these studies, we proposed Ce1− x Zr x O2 as promising support materials for the nitrite reduction. Thus, our objective was to investigate the effect of the oxygen vacancy on the catalytic nitrite reduction in water over a series of Pd/Ce1− x Zr x O2 catalysts with varying Zr contents. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation Ce1− x Zr x O2 (x =0, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7) supports were prepared by the co-precipitation method described in the previous studies [22–24]. Stoichiometric amount of cerium(III) nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, Aldrich, 99%) and zirconium(IV) oxide chloride octahydrate (ZrOCl2·8H2O, Sigma–Aldrich, 98%) were dissolved in deionized water (solution; 0.1M), which was adjusted pH to 8 using ammonium hydroxide (28% NH4OH, Sigma–Aldrich). The solution was vigorously stirred at 80°C for 3h and then washed using deionized water until chloride ion was not detected. The washed sample was dried at 100°C for 24h, followed by calcined at 400°C for 4h in air. Pd was impregnated using the deposition–precipitation method [25], and the amount of Pd was fixed at 3wt.% in all the catalysts. Palladium chloride (PdCl2, Aldrich, 99.9%) and the synthesized support were dissolved in 0.01M of HCl solution, which was then heated to 75°C. Thereafter, 1M Na2CO3 solution was slowly added to the mixed solution under vigorous stirring until a pH of 10 was reached. After 3h of stirring, the solution was filtered and washed several times with deionized water. The resulting solid was dried at 100°C overnight and calcined at 400°C for 4h. Finally, all the prepared catalysts were reduced with H2/N2 (10% vol%) at 200°C for 2h before the reaction tests. The abbreviations of the Pd/Ce1− x Zr x O2 catalysts are listed in Table 1 . 2.2 Catalyst characterization The contents of Pd and Ce/Zr molar ratio in the Pd/Ce1− x Zr x O2 catalysts were analyzed by inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES, Thermo Instrument, Polyscan 61E). The surface areas of catalysts were measured by the nitrogen adsorption–desorption method using a BET instrument (BEL Japan Inc. BELSORP MAX). Before the measurement, catalysts were pretreated at 373K under vacuum to remove the moisture and impurities in the catalysts. X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed using an X-ray powder diffractometer (Rigaku, ATX-G) using Cu Kα (λ =1.5406Å) irradiation to determine the crystal structure of the support and palladium. The diffraction patterns were scanned in the 2θ range from 10° to 80° at a scanning rate of 2°/min. Raman spectra were recorded at room temperature using a Raman spectrometer (Horiba Jobin Yvon, LabRam Aramis). The data were detected with 514.5nm line of Ar–ion laser. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was performed with a PHI 5000 Versa Probe equipped with an Al Kα X-ray source (1486.6eV), and binding energies were corrected with C1s referenced at 284.6eV. 2.3 Reaction test The reaction test was performed on a semi batch reactor at 25°C and atmospheric pressure. Before the test, the catalyst (0.3g) was suspended in 295mL of deionized water and purged with nitrogen to remove remaining air. After the purging, hydrogen gas at a flow rate of 90mL/min was used as the reducing agent, and 5mL of nitrite solution (2mM of KNO2, Sigma–Aldrich) was injected in the reactor. In order to improve the activity, CO2 gas was added as a pH buffer. During the reaction test, the samples were periodically withdrawn to estimate the catalytic performance. Nitrite ion concentration was determined by high performance liquid chromatography (Young-Lin) using a Zorbax Eclipse C18 column with a UV detector at a wavelength of 210nm. The mobile phase consisted of 0.01M of octylammonium orthophosphate and methanol. Ammonium ion was measured using ion chromatography (Dionex, thermal conductivity detector) with an IonPac CS12A column and methanesulfonic acid (20mM) as the mobile phase. The conversion of nitrite was calculated by Eq. (1). (1) Nitrite Conversion , X NO 2 − ( % ) = C ( NO 2 − ) i − C ( NO 2 − ) f C ( NO 2 − ) i × 100 The selectivity of ammonium ion and nitrogen yield were calculated by Eqs. (2) and (3). (2) Ammonium selectivity , S NH 4 + ( % ) = C ( NH 4 + ) C ( N O 2 − ) i − C ( NO 2 − ) f × 100 (3) Nitrogen yield ( % ) = X NO 2 − × ( 100 − S NH 4 + ) 100 3 Results and discussion 3.1 BET, XRD and Raman analysis BET surface areas and pore volumes of Pd/Ce1− x Zr x O2 catalysts (PC and PCZ) are listed in Table 1. The specific surface area increased with increasing Zr content (i.e., PC→PCZ3), and the present result was similar to those reported by Levasseur et al. and Terribile et al. [26,27]. The trend of surface area variation might arise from that the Zr insertion-induced phase transformation from a cubic CeO2 to a tetragonal ZrO2, preventing the sintering of the catalysts, and the results were consistent with the XRD result. In contrast, there was no relationship between the Zr content and pore volume. Fig. 1 shows the X-ray diffraction (XRD) profiles of the catalysts. For PC catalyst, the diffraction peaks corresponding to the cubic CeO2 phase were observed at 2θ values of 28.5°, 33°, 47.4°, 56.2°, 59°, 69.5°, 76.6°, and 79°, which were slightly shifted to the high 2θ value with increasing Zr content. This could be attributed to the shrinkage of the lattice due to the substitution of Ce3+ (1.10Å) for Zr4+ (0.87Å) with smaller ionic radius [28,29]. When x increased from 0.3 to 0.7, the tetragonal phase of ZrO2 appeared in the XRD spectra, whereas the cubic CeO2 peaks became weaker and broader. With regard to Pd species, a weak metallic Pd peak at 2θ value of 40° was observed in PCZ2 and PCZ3 catalysts, whereas there was no peak related to Pd in the XRD spectra of PC and PCZ1 catalysts. The Raman spectra of the catalysts are shown in Fig. 2 . In the Ce-rich catalysts (e.g., PC and PCZ1), sharp band related to the F2g vibration mode of cubic CeO2 phase was observed at 465cm−1 [30–32]. The band was shifted to higher frequencies and became weaker as the Zr content increased, probably attributed to the distortion of CeO2 lattice by the displacement of Ce3+ with Zr4+ [28,33]. Compared to the Raman spectrum of Pd-free CeO2 support (data not shown), a very broad band in the range 600–650cm−1 was observed for the PC catalyst, which was attributed to the formation of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface [29,34]. For the catalysts with a composition of 0.3≤ x ≤0.7, we also found the presence of oxygen vacancies in the spectra, although the band was affected by the growth of the tetragonal phase. Based on the results, it was tentatively expected that the oxygen vacancies were generated in the CeO2-containing catalysts. 3.2 XPS analysis Fig. 3 (a) and (b) show Ce 3 d and O 1 XPS spectra for the Pd/Ce1− x Zr x O2 catalysts, respectively. The Ce 3d spectra (Fig. 3(a)) were complicated because of the hybridization between Ce 4f and O 2p states [34,35]. The Ce 3d spectra could be deconvoluted into 10 peaks which were composed of two groups (i) v (v 0, v, v′, v″, v‴) and (ii) u (u 0, u, u″, u″, u‴) [36]. The final states of the deconvoluted peaks are known as follows: v 0 and u 0 (Ce 3d9 4f2, O 2p5), v and u (Ce 3d9 4f2, O 2p4), v′ and u′ (Ce 3d9 4f1, O 2p6), v″ and u″ (Ce 3d9 4f1, O 2p5), and v‴ and u‴ (Ce 3d9 4f0, O 2p6) [36]. The peaks of v 0, v′, u 0, u′ were assigned to Ce3+, and the other peaks were attributed to the Ce4+ state [36,37]. From the previous study [38,39], the Ce3+ concentrations in the catalysts were calculated using Eq. (4), and listed in Table 2 . The Ce3+ is related to the formation of oxygen vacancies [40,41]. (4) Ce 3 + concentration = ( v 0 + v ′ + u 0 + u ′ ) Σ( v i + u i ) The Ce3+ concentration of the catalysts decreased in the following order: PCZ1 (34.9%)>PCZ2 (31.4%)>PC (27.1%)>PCZ3 (24.9%). Reddy et al. and Paier et al. reported that the amount of oxygen vacancies formed on the surface of the catalyst was proportional to the Ce3+ concentration [34,40], indicating that PCZ1 had an oxygen vacancy rich surface. This trend was also observed in the O 1s spectra (Fig. 3(b)). The spectra were deconvoluted into three peaks; The first peak (∼530eV) was attributed to lattice oxygen of the metal oxides, the second peak (∼531.5eV) was ascribed to the chemisorbed surface oxygen, and the peak located at the highest binding energy (∼533.3eV) was assigned to oxygen absorbed on Ce3+ formed at the surface [42]. In the previous studies, the oxygen vacancies amount were associated with the ratio of the second peak area (noted as A c ) to the total peak area (noted as At ) [38,43,44]. The order of the ratio was PCZ1 (30.2%)>PCZ2 (26.4%)>PC (25.1%)>PCZ3 (23.8%) as listed in Table 2, which also presented that PCZ1 catalyst contained the highest amount of oxygen vacancies among all the catalysts. Earlier study claimed that the Ce1− x Zr x O2 mixed oxides could be formed as following Eq. (5) [26]. (5) CeO 2 + Zr 4 + → Ce 1 − x Zr x O 2 → Ce 1 − x Z r x O 2 − y + 1 2 y O 2 The addition of Zr4+ into the CeO2 lattice could cause the reduction of Ce4+ to Ce3+ and facilitate the oxygen mobility over the catalyst, resulting in increased the number of oxygen vacancies [26,45]. From these results, the more reduced states on PCZ1 and PCZ2 catalysts might be because of a defect structure induced by the insertion of appropriate amount (x =0.3 and 0.5) of Zr to the CeO2 [29,30]. However, the lowest Ce3+ concentration on PCZ3 catalyst resulted from a high Zr amount (x =0.7), forming the irreducible structure. 3.3 Reaction tests The catalytic performances for the nitrite reduction were estimated under a pure H2 flow. Fig. 4 shows the concentration profiles of nitrite and ammonium as a function of the reaction time. The nitrite gradually reduced as the reaction proceeds. The Ce1− x Zr x O2 mixed oxide supported catalysts with compositions of x =0.3 and 0.5 (PCZ1 and PCZ2) completely reduced the nitrite in 60 and 80min, respectively, which were much faster than that (120min) of the Pd/CeO2 catalyst (PC). On the other hand, it was observed that the poorest activity was obtained when x =0.7 (PCZ3). Considering the nitrite consumption rate, the order of the activity was the following: PCZ1>PCZ2>PC>PCZ3. Notably, the most enhanced activity was observed at the use of Ce0.7Zr0.3O2 support. The concentration of ammonium increased over reaction time, resulting in low N2 yields for all the catalysts at the completion of the reaction (PC: 40.6%, PCZ1: 45.4%, PCZ2: 41.5% and PCZ3: 40.4%). This was probably due to a high pH environment (above 11) resulting from the production of hydroxide ions during the nitrite reduction (Fig. 4(a)). The Hörold group reported that the ammonium formation was favored in the high pH conditions [2]. In order to lower pH values, Qian et al. used CO2 gas as a pH buffer for the nitrite reduction [46]. Accordingly, we tested the PCZ1 catalyst (which had the best activity) under constant H2 flow rate of 90mL/min and varied CO2 of 10, 30, 60 and 90mL/min. The reaction results under H2/CO2 gas are shown in Fig. 5 . The remarkable effect of CO2 addition was observed in the nitrite reduction rate, which became much faster than that in the case of pure H2 flow. As a result, nitrite was completely reduced within even 3min when the feed gas composition was H2:CO2 =1:1 (90:90, in mL/min). Chinthaginjala et al. found a similar phenomenon that the adsorption of nitrite was enhanced at low pH conditions, which resulted in increasing reaction rate [47]. Furthermore, co-fed CO2 gas also decreased the pH values below 6.5 during the reaction, and thus the final concentrations of ammonium were lowered. Regarding the concentrations of nitrite and ammonium at 3min, the best result (Nitrite conversion: 100%, N2 yield: 90.5%) was obtained at a gas compositions of H2 (90mL/min)/CO2 (90mL/min). It is worth noting that the nitrite reduction activity was closely related to the surface state of the Pd/Ce1− x Zr x O2 catalysts. The moderate amount of Zr (x =0.3 and 0.5) introduced in the ceria lattice distorted the structure, generating more oxygen vacancies (larger Ce3+ concentration) than the Pd/CeO2 catalyst, as revealed in the XPS result. In our previous study for the nitrate reduction using the Pd–Cu/TiO2 catalyst, we reported that the nitrate was adsorbed on the oxygen vacancies of reducible TiO2 support, and then the weakly bonded nitrate could be easily removed on the active metal [13]. Other research groups dealt with the reducible supports such as CeO2 and SnO2 also claimed that the nitrate was reduced by the interaction of the oxygen atoms of nitrate with oxygen vacancies [16,17,48]. Based on the above discussions, we speculated that the nitrite reduction occurred as follows: During the reaction, nitrite could be coordinated with the oxygen vacancies, then weakly bonded nitrite was easily reduced to nitrogen or ammonium by chemisorbed hydrogen atoms on Pd. Thus, the largest amount of those vacancies formed on PCZ1 gave rise to the highest activity. 4 Conclusions In this study, we prepared a series of Pd/Ce1− x Zr x O2 catalysts (where x =0, 0.3, 0.5 and 0.7) and evaluated their activities. The catalytic activity was in the following order: Pd/Ce0.7Zr0.3O2 >Pd/Ce0.5Zr0.5O2 >Pd/CeO2 >Pd/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2. Based on the Ce 3d and O 1s XPS spectra, we found that the activity trend was in good agreement with the trend in the portion of oxygen vacancies on the surface of the catalysts, indicating that the oxygen vacancies functioned as the active sites (interaction with oxygen atoms of nitrite) for the nitrite reduction. Therefore, the insertion of proper amount of Zr to the Pd/CeO2 catalyst was the decisive factor in promoting the nitrite reduction activity. coredata.dc:description: In this study, we tested Pd/Ce1− x Zr x O2 catalysts (x =0, 0.3, 0.5 and 0.7) for nitrite reduction in water. The Ce1− x Zr x O2 was synthesized by the co-precipitation method, and Pd was impregnated on the support using the deposition–precipitation method. The introduction of Zr into the ceria lattice of the catalyst with x =0.3 and 0.5 distorted the lattice structure, accordingly, both the catalysts easily reduced nitrite than the pure CeO2 supported Pd catalyst. In contrast, the Pd/Ce0.3Zr0.7O2 (x =0.7) catalyst became difficult to reduce as the tetragonal ZrO2 phase was dominant in the catalyst structure. These phenomena led to the difference in the amount of oxygen vacancies on the surface of the catalyst. In the nitrite reduction test, the catalyst containing more oxygen vacancies showed higher activity. The relationships between the catalytic activities and the surface properties with composition of the support over Pd/Ce1− x Zr x O2 catalysts were investigated by X-ray diffraction (XRD), Raman spectroscopy and X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analyses.
coredata.dc:title: Catalytic reduction of nitrite in water over ceria- and ceria–zirconia-supported Pd catalysts
